name: Iron Age
description: The age where you master the skills of smelting and working with iron and iron based alloys.

quests.name: Bloomery
quests.description: Where we learned the secret to smelting iron.

tasks.longDescription: To make wrought iron you will need to make a bloomery. First you need to craft a bloomery block, which is crafted with 8 bronze double sheets of any type. A bloomery is a multiblock structure. To build it place a 3x3 set of bricks on the ground, then build up one but leave in the inside and one outside block free. Next add one block on each cardinal side (nswe). This is the smallest build for a bloomery. To make it larger you can increase it's height two blocks. See the TFC wiki for diagrams.

Place 8 charcoal in the bottom then throw an 8 ore pieces (regardless of quality) and 8 charcoal down the chimney. You can add an additional 8 ore and charcoal per extra layer for a total of 24 pieces. Afterwards light the bloomery block with a fire-starter or flint and steel. In a few hours you will have a raw bloom, which your harvest with a pick axe.

Once you have a raw bloom from the bloomery, the first step is to heat it up in your forge until it is hot enough to be worked in a bronze anvil. After this hammer the bloom into a refined bloom. Next you will need to split the bloom. The last step is to either hammer each 100 unit bar into a wrought iron bar or to melt them down in the crucible.

quests.name: Bellows
quests.description: Where we learned how to make the forge hotter

tasks.longDescription: The bellows can be placed next to a firepit, forge or blast furnace. Face the direction you want it to face to place. It must be placed on top of a solid block. Right clicking will increase the heat temporarily at the cost of fuel. This does not increase the rate items heat or process in the Blast furnace.

quests.name: Crucible
quests.description: Where we learned that we can melt metals over a forge.

tasks.longDescription: Fire clay is a useful material, since it makes ceramics that are resistant to heat.
The crucible can be placed on top of your forge. When heated up you can place most metals inside to melt them. This is useful for mixing alloys.

quests.name: Black Steel
quests.description: Where we learned to make steel stronger

tasks.longDescription: To make black steel you will need to start by making weak steel in a crucible. Weak steel is an unrefined alloy of steel, nickel, and black bronze. Use NEI to see the ratios. To make single ingot of black steel, you will also need to get a pig iron ingot to weld to the weak steel ingot.
Now you need to weld the pig iron and the weak steel ingots together. After this it needs to be worked on your anvil to remove impurities.

quests.name: Blue Steel
quests.description: Where we learned to make heat resistant steel

tasks.longDescription: To make blue steel you will need to start by making weak blue steel in a crucible. Weak blue steel is an alloy of black steel, bismuth bronze, sterling silver, and steel. Use NEI to see the ratios. To make single ingot of blue steel, you will also need to get a black steel ingot to weld to the weak blue steel ingot.
Now you need to weld the black steel and the weak blue steel ingots together. After this it needs to be worked on your anvil to remove impurities.

quests.name: Red Steel
quests.description: Where we learned to make currosition and pressure resistant steel

tasks.longDescription: To make red steel you will need to start by making weak red steel in a crucible. Weak red steel is an alloy of black steel, rose gold, brass, and steel. Use NEI to see the ratios. To make single ingot of red steel, you will also need to get a black steel ingot to weld to the weak red steel ingot.
Now you need to weld the black steel and the weak red steel ingots together. After this it needs to be worked on your anvil to remove impurities.

quests.name: Blast Furnace
quests.description: Where we learned to smelt iron at higher temperatures to make pig iron

tasks.longDescription: The blast furnance is a multiblock structure used to turn iron ore into pig ironï¿½?.

The first part of the blast furnace you will need to build is its chimney. To start place four fire brick blocks in a cross shape around an empty block. Make sure to leave two blocks empty underneath where the blast furnace and crucible will go. Next Place a wrought iron sheet on each side of the chimney blocks other than the top or bottom. You can extend the size of the chimney up to 6 high.

To finish the blast furnace place a crucible and the blast furnace on top, one block bellow the chimney. Next put a bellows pointing towards the blast furnace. Remember you need to place the bellows on a solid block. You will also need a tuyere, which is placed in the blast furnace GUI. The blast furnace will heat, but you will be unable to pump the pig iron out without it. The tuyere is smithed from a double metal sheet. Any kind will do. Now drop 4 charcoal, 4 iron ore, and 4 flux powder into the chimney. Light the blast furnace. Keep an eye on the blast furnace and add more charcoal if its level drops below the ore in the GUI. There is no need to pump the bellows until the pig iron has formed, you'll need to figure out when that is. Once the pig iron is formed you can pump the bellows to allow the pig iron to flow through the tuyere into the crucible.

Now that you have a crucible full of pig iron, you will need to process it. Like with iron, you will need to pour out the iron from the crucible into a ingot mold. It is best to start pouring ingots while pumping the pig iron into the crucible. When the pig iron is solid, but still hot enough, hammer out the impurities on your anvil.

quests.name: Metal Buckets
quests.description: Where we learned to make a bucket that can carry lava

tasks.longDescription: Blue steel seems to be the only alloy strong enough to tolerate the intense heat of carrying lava.

Now that you know how to make wrought iron, you can make a pair of shears. Although you can shear a sheep with a knife, shears will give more wool. They are also a very useful tool for breaking leaves. Start by making two wrought iron knife heads
Now that you have two knife heads, place both of them in your anvils work area. you should now be able to select the shears blueprint.

The grill allows you to cook more than one food item at once, but each item must be less than 80 oz. To setup the grill, place directly on a forge. Alternatively place a 2 brick high pillar on the left and right of a firepit. Then place the grill directly on the pit.

quests.name: Non-tool making Alloys
quests.description: Where we learned of a few more alloys that we may need later but cannot be used for making tools

tasks.longDescription: Brass is a alloy of copper and sphalerite(zinc). It can be mixed in a crucible or pit kiln. The ratio is between 88% and 92% copper and between 8% and 12% zinc.
Rose gold is an alloy of gold and copper. It can be mixed in a crucible or pit kiln. The ratio is between 70% and 85% gold and between 15% and 30% copper.
Sterling silver is an alloy of Copper and Silver. It can be mixed in a crucible or pit kiln. The ratio is between 60% and 80% silver and between 20% and 40% copper.

quests.name: Steel furnace
quests.description: Where we learned of advanced smelting technology

tasks.longDescription: Now that we know how to make steel we can make a furnace to handle tasks like smelting cobblestone and firing clay.

quests.name: Red Buckets
quests.description: Where we learned to move water

tasks.longDescription: Red steel is the first metal you have found that is resilient enough hold an entire source block of water.
